AM Anne-Marie Slaughter professor politics international affairs Princeton. By Anne-Marie Slaughter PRESIDENT Obama says noose tightening around Col. Muammar al-Qaddafi. In fact, tightening around Libyan rebels, Colonel Qaddafi makes world's dithering steadily retakes rebel-held tow.ns, The United States Europe temporizing no-flight zone Organization Islamic Conference, Gulf Cooperation Council Arab League called United Nations Security Council authorize one. Opponents no- flight zone put forth five main arguments, none which, closer examination, hold up. It's interest. Gen. Wesley K. Clark argues "Libya doesn't sell much oil United States" Americans "want support democratic movements region," already Iraq Afghanistan. Framing issue terms oil exactly Arab populations indeed much world expect, cynical professions support democracy human rights. Now chance support new beginning Muslim world — new beginning accountable governments provide services opportunities citizens ways could dramatically decrease support terrorist groups violent extremism. It's hard imagine something strategic interest. It counter-productive. Many thoughtful commentators, including Al Jazeera's director general, Wadah Khanfar, argue important Arab spring coming Arabs themselves. From perspective, Western military intervention play right Qaddati's hands, allowing broadcast pictures Western bombs falling Arab civilians. But arguments, important, must weighed appeals Libyan opposition fighters asking international help, now, astonishingly, support no-flight zone governments kept populations quiescent holding specter foreign intervention. Assuming no-flight zone imposed international coalition includes Arab states, opportunity establish new narrative Western support Arab democrats. By Stephen Prothero, Special CNN What make attacks U.S. consulates Egypt, Libya Yemen, deaths four Americans, including U.S. ambassador Libya Chris Stevens? It depends mean "we." From perspective stormed embassies, taking American flag Egypt replacing black flag reading, "There God Allah Mohammed messenger," act justice behalf One True Faith. And creation anti-Islamic video (ironically entitled "Innocence Muslims") producer thought American provided catalyst (or excuse) protests. Why Muslims sensitive portraying Prophet Mohammed Most Americans operate different "we." From perspective, assault unjust cowardly attack (among things) rule law, institution diplomacy right free speech. Libyan Deputy Prime Minister Mustafa Abushagur gave voice perspective said Twitter, "I condemn barbaric attacks strongest possible terms. This attack America, Libya free people everywhere." "Some sought justify vicious behavior response inflammatory material posted Internet," Secretary State Hillary Clinton added. "The United States deplores intentional effort denigrate religious beliefs others. Our commitment religious tolerance goes back beginning nation." This unconscious "default setting" fosters sort "blind certainty" manifests arrogant atheism fundamentalism alike, Wallace said. And point education shake us "default setting" — begin see things perspectives others. This it. Pretty uncompelling piece ask me, course I'm biased. Mitt Romney: A New Course Middle East Restore three sinews American influence: economic strength, military strength strength values. Disturbing developments sweeping across greater Middle East. In Syria, tens thousands innocent people slaughtered. In Egypt, Muslim Brotherhood come power, country's peace treaty Israel hangs In balance. In Libya, ambassador murdered In terrorist attack. U.S. embassies throughout region stormed violent protests. And Iran, ayatollahs continue move full tilt toward nuclear-weapons capability, promising annihilate Israel. These developments not, President Obama says, mere "bumps road." They major issues put security risk. Yet amid upheaval, country seems mercy events rather shaping them. We're moving direction protects people allies. And that's dangerous. If Middle East descends chaos, Iran moves toward nuclear breakout, Israel's security compromised, America could pulled maelstrom. We still time address threats, require new strategy toward Middle East The first step understand got here. Since World War II, America leader Free World. We're unique earned role conquest promoting human rights, free markets rule law. We ally like-minded countries, expand prosperity trade keep peace maintaining military second none. But recent years, President Obama allowed leadership atrophy. Our economy stuck "recovery" barely deserves name. Our national debt risen record levels. Our military, tested decade war, facing devastating cuts thanks budgetary games played White House. Finally, values misapplied—and misunderstood—by president thinks weakness win favor adversaries. By failing maintain elements influence stepping away allies, President Obama heightened prospect conflict instability. He understand American policy lacks resolve provoke aggression encourage disorder. The Middle East case point. The Arab Spring presented opportunity help move millions people oppression freedom. But also presented grave risks. We needed strategy success, president offered none. And seeks downplay significance calamities past weeks The incomprehension afflicts president's policy toward Israel. The president began term explicit policy creating "daylight" two countries. He recently downgraded Israel "closest ally" Middle East "one closest allies." It's diplomatic message received clearly Israel adversaries alike. He dismissed Israel's concerns Iran mere "noise" prefers "block out." And time Israel needs America stand it, declined meet Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. In period uncertainty, need apply coherent strategy supporting partners Middle East—that is, governments individuals share values. This means restoring credibility Iran. When say Iranian nuclear-weapons capability—and regional instability comes it--is unacceptable, ayatollahs must made believe us. It means placing daylight United States Israel, And means using full spectrum soft power encourage liberty opportunity long known corruption oppression. The dignity work ability steer course lives best alternatives extremism. But Middle East policy undermined unless restore three sinews influence: economic strength, military strength strength Of values. That require different set policies President Obama pursuing. Person Interest: United States UN Ambassador Susan Rice Oct 8, 2012 iloo AM EDT Leslie H. Gelb A diplomat fire. With presidential campaign drowning boredom, commentators desperately searching news, preferably new victim, brighten days. And along came Susan Rice. A couple Sundays ago, U.N. ambassador made mistake appearing talk shows insist attack U.S. consulate Benghazi, Libya, "spontaneous" rather terrorist plot. You would thought said pope Mormon. Out came Washington daggers. She lied. She shill. Benghazi spontaneous event. It work al Qaeda offshoot. The White House fumbled key intelligence information trying cover unforgivable mistake. Rice covering president. Her reward would Obama's nominating succeed Hillary Clinton secretary State. The commentariat immediately rolled plans nail Rice Obama team wall. Peter King, Grand Inquisitor Republicans House Representatives, pledged "investigate" hold hearings. And that, said commentariat, would end Rice's hopes become new Hillary. Associated Press Published September 21, 2012 BENGHAZI, lli3YA — Hundreds protesters angry last week's killing U.S. ambassador Libya stormed compound Islamic extremist militia suspected attack, evicting militiamen setting fire building Friday. In unprecedented show public anger Libya's rampant militias, crowd overwhelmed compound Ansar Al-Sharlah Brigade center eastern city Benghazi. Ansar Al-Shariah fighters initially fired air disperse crowd, eventually abandoned site weapons vehicles overrun waves protesters shouting "No militias." "I don't want see armed men wearing Afghani-style clothes stopping street give orders, I want see people uniform," said Omar Mohammed, university student took part takeover site, protesters said done support army police. No deaths reported incident, came tens thousands marched Benghazi armed militias. One vehicle also burned compound. For many Libyans, Sept. 11 attack U.S. Consulate Benghazi last straw one biggest problems Libya faced since ouster death longtime dictator Moamrnar Qaddafi around year ago -- multiple mini-armies arsenals machine guns rocket-propelled grenades stronger regular armed forces police. The militias, legacy rag-tag popular forces fought Qaddafi's regime, tout protectors Libya's revolution, providing security police cannot. But many say act like gangs, detaining intimidating rivals carrying killings. Militias made Islamic radicals like Ansar Al-Shariah notorious attacks Muslims don't abide hardline ideology. Officials witnesses say fighters Ansar Al-Shariati led attack U.S. consulate, killed Amb. Chris Stevens three Americans. After taking Ansar compound, protesters drove attack Benghazi headquarters another Islamist militia, Rafallah Sahati. The militiamen opened fire protesters, largely unarmed. At least 20 wounded, unconfirmed witness reports three protesters killed. Earlier day, 30,000 people filled broad boulevard marched along lake central Benghazi Friday gates headquarters Ansar Al-Shariah. "No, no, militias," crowd chanted, filling broad boulevard. They carried banners signs demanding militias disband government build police take place keeping security. "Benghazi trap," signs read. "Where army, police?" However, militias join still abide government authority, critics say lure salaries prompted militias form. Officials former rebel commanders estimate number rebels actually fought 8-month civil war Gadhafi around 30,000. But listed High Security Committee payroll reached several hundred thousand. "All militia entities fake ones mushrooming," said Khaled Hadar, Benghazi-based lawyer. 'The government making temporarily solutions, creating disaster." ### U.S. Department State Case No. F-2015-04841 Doc No. C05739766 Date: 05/13/2015 STATE DEPT. - PRODUCED TO HOUSE SELECT BENGHAZI COMM. By Sarah Chayes November 15, 2012 The scandal enveloping members America's adulated top brass deepest crisis hit military decades. It crisis President Obama need — shaming country increasing burden major transition national security team. And yet, crisis great corrective. The suspicion reflected fraught National Security Council debate Afghanistan strategy 2009. Yet since then, Obama, like many others, seems seduced Petraeus. Not man man could offer him. Hillary Clinton Embraces New Media By MATTHEW LEE AP Sat, Mar 21, 2009 WASHINGTON (AP) — Her videos aren't quite viral yet she's tweeting, Secretary State Hillary Rodham Clinton embracing new media, using Web promote agency role nation's top envoy. In less three months, Clinton's State Department embarked digital diplomacy drive aimed spreading word American foreign policy restoring Washington's image. Part broader Internet outreach President Barack Obama's administration, Clinton's Web efforts already outpaced predecessors. Since taking Foggy Bottom, Clinton's team built e-diplomacy innovations developed George W. Bush's presidency: - They revamped department's Web site (http://www.state.gov) Dipnote blog (http://blogs.state.gov http://twitter.com/dipnote) fresh array features, graphics colorful posts. - Users track foreign travel interactive map (http://www.state.gov/secretary/trvI/map/?trip_id5) - They keep virtually every move Facebook, Twitter, Flickr YouTube (http://www.youtube.com/user/statevideo). - They pose questions "ask-the-secretary" column (http://www.state.gov/r/pa/ei/ask/secretary/117297.htm) recently revised "text secretary." (http://www.state.gov/r/pa/ei/ask/secretary/120236.htm) "New media critical new era diplomacy, smart power expanded dialogues essential achieving foreign policy goals," said Cheryl Mills, Clinton's longtime confidante chief staff. Even government Web site, early indications show surge interest, according internal State Department statistics provided The Associated Press. Daily views Dipnote doubled 10,000 year ago 20,000 today, 700 subscribers RSS feed, twice many March 2008. The number followers department Twitter tripled since Jan. 20, Obama took office, department's Facebook friends increased 2 1/2 times period. 8 "What bringing willingness experiment," said Peter Daou, Clinton's Web guru 2008 presidential run. "They starting push envelope." What remains unclear, though, whether spike interest reflects revamped Web site public's fascination Clinton's latest career shift. "The personality behind can't dismissed," said Daou, blogs human rights issues U.N. Dispatch (http://www.undispatch.com). Like Obama, Clinton carries Blackberry, allowed use department's secure seventh floor office is. Aides say takes active role answering questions Web, responding bloggers pushing agency's new media agenda. "The United States Government behind nearly everybody, except certain discrete areas, terms technology," told department employees town hall meeting February. "We are, view, wasting time, wasting money, wasting opportunities, prepared communicate effectively business world private world." Clinton quick embrace new media start presidential campaign. She announced entry race February 2007 Web followed regular Internet chats Internet fundraising appeals. Nonetheless, Clinton surpassed Obama campaign's mastery Internet social networking sites. Obama used Web raise record donations identify orchestrate army volunteers. Clinton first lady first White House Web site debuted 1994. It bare-bones operation compared available now. Three years later, State Department went online Secretary State Madeleine Albright's tenure. But wasn't 2007, Secretary State Condoleezza Rice's spokesman, Sean McCormack, department's public affairs shop began exploring new media earnest. McCormack started Dipnote blog, foreign service veterans predicted would fail, given private stuffy nature diplomacy. The site endured Rice. Clinton retooled Dipnote Twitter feed broader range posts diplomats. It's window dressing. This past week, diplomats used Twitter "tweet" false rumors feared might lead siege U.S. Embassy Madagascar. On first two foreign trips, Asia Middle East Europe, local bloggers "embedded" traveling press corps, broadening audience Clinton's official meetings public appearances, often produce personal policy questions. On question site, Clinton responded varied questions, "Should U.S. engage direct dialogue Hamas?" "How like meeting Japanese students?" By end Clinton's trip Mideast, "text secretary" feature received nearly 2,000 text messages. On trips, Clinton also participated Webcasts. One Beijing climate change generated 10.2 million page views, 50,000 comments 7,000 questions, according statistics. Clinton's staff say plan venture realm social networking, animated online world called Second Life, cell phone technology. The department hopes follow Bush administration organized 9 project brought together Facebook, Google, Howcast, YouTube, AT&T, MTV, Columbia Law School, Access360Media Gen-Next Alliance Youth Movements summit. It also wants expand X-Life, mobile phone game launched February aimed helping youth Middle East learn English teaching American history, culture values. Copyright © 2009 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. 10

April 11, 2009 12pm Word count: 2,392 (19 min) Rooney (x7-7203, 202-431-6498) SECRETARY OF STATE HILLARY RODHAM CLINTON REMARKS TO THE HAITI DONORS CONFERENCE Washington, D.C. Tuesday, April 14, 2009 For us, Haiti neighbor. For others, place historic cultural ties. For us, test collective commitment resolve. Some may ask small nation middle Caribbean Sea command attention today. Why countries Western Hemisphere, Europe, Middle East Asia offer assistance Haiti midst global economic downturn shaken us all. We're gathered conference happens Haiti resound far beyond Caribbean beyond Americas. The success failure one small nation economic, social political implications, 9 million citizens, region whose future shaped strength commitment achieve economic recovery, political progress wider opportunity people Portland Porto Alegre Port-au-Prince. The United States here, first foremost, right thing neighbor friend. Our ties Haiti reach back early years nations endured generations-through struggles independence; defeat slavery Haiti, inspired slaves abolitionists U.S. press fight freedom; recently, hundreds thousands Haitians emigrated United States strengthened contributions politics, business, science, sports culture-the benefits I experienced firsthand senator representing New York. We also committed creating hemisphere every nation-no matter present level wealth current political circumstances-is moving direction, toward greater peace, prosperity, freedom opportunity. With Haiti, chance global cooperation collaboration stand solidarity people seeking march forward. A nation small investments assistance countries beginning reap dividends economic growth, wider access health care, stronger governmental institutions, greater safety security-and higher quality life results material conditions people's lives improve. Today, Haiti poorest nation hemisphere, one region's biggest gaps haves have- nots. But 2006, Haiti highest economic growth since 1990s. It track reach completion point IMF's Heavily Indebted Poor Countries Initiative next months, means significant debt relief way, free approximately $4 million month-money Haiti invest directly improving lives people building future self-sufficiency confidence. Haiti region's highest rate HIV/AIDS, highest rate maternal mortality, highest rate child mortality. But numbers HIV infections child maternal deaths coming down. Not long ago, Haiti endured three decades brutal dictatorship. But national presidential elections 2006 jump-started Haiti's democracy, President Preval Prime Minister Pierre Louis seeking maintain strong commitment democratic governance, take another step forward Sunday elections Senate. Like many nations, including United States, Haiti struggles crime, particularly global scourge drug trafficking. But reforms improve policing, strengthen justice system fight corruption underway, peacekeeping force led Brazil helped bring stability many Haitian communities. Haiti made strides help citizens many nations institutions represented today. And progress come government-to-government partnerships, also links among businesses, universities, NG0s, religious cultural groups, individuals-the full range resources relationships, heart smart power. That trajectory progress undermined combined winds hurricanes global economic recession. Haiti danger stalling. This conference gives us opportunity reignite path progress work team-with Haiti helm-to advance comprehensive, long-term strategy Haiti's growth, coordinating hemispheric international efforts, targeting clear goals, deploying diverse skills resources efficiently effectively. President Preval Prime Minister Pierre Louis identified help Haiti needs get back track. With priorities guide Haiti partner, make high-impact investments help lay foundation stronger democratic institutions, vibrant civil society, open market economy creates stability, attracts international investment, offers jobs wider economic opportunities Haiti region whole. Now time step investment Haiti-not situation dire, consequences inaction could lead significantly larger costs human financial terms road. With $100, pay year schooling one Haitian child immunize five. That's tiny fraction cost solving problems escalate time. The United States target support toward three areas Haitian government requested, aimed promoting conditions essential national regional progress. First, Haitian people need secure. They must able travel safely work school participate civic lives communities without fear violence. Second, country needs stronger infrastructure, particularly roads, circulatory system robust economy. Meanwhile, people Haiti ready work, jobs short supply. We accomplish two things putting people work building roads infrastructure throughout Haiti. And third, last year's hurricanes blew hole government's budget. Now Haiti facing huge deficit, make harder provide services short-term fund major projects long-term. Their debt obligations constrain ability lay groundwork future. On issues-security, jobs infrastructure, debt relief-the United States lending assistance seeking partner nations maximize collective impact. First, security. Effective international partnerships already helped stem violence improve security Haiti. Cite Soleil, example, no-man's-land years, today, violence subsided new sense freedom felt streets. The Haitian National Police supported work UN peacekeeping operation Haiti, first hemisphere Latin American Caribbean nations participated. Brazil led mission determination skill. This level engagement collaboration major step forward region. But criminal networks operating Haiti eliminated. Haiti continues fight drug traffickers made country distribution point illegal drugs headed United States, Canada Europe. Drug trafficking problem involves many nations, role play ending deadly trade. That includes United States. We give $2 million fight drug trafficking Haiti Merida Initiative, plan conceived Mexico, Central America United States. This money fund secure communications network Haitian police; provide maritime base, vehicles operational support police drug units; provide training promote cross-border cooperation Haiti Dominican Republic; sharpen investigation prosecution drug crimes. Once security established, opportunity take root. Nations Canada Spain Japan offered generous assistance help repair damage last year's storms. Now time take next step-to move beyond peacekeeping disaster relief long-term reconstruction development. Haiti highest unemployment rate hemisphere; 70 percent people don't jobs. It also one region's highest population growth rates. Together, trends created one development expert called "youth tsunami"-nearly 1 million youths expected come job market next five years. To spur creation jobs, United States passed HOPE Act 2006, give garments made Haiti tariff-free access U.S. market. Last October, extended trade preference another decade. Apparel one largest sectors Haiti's economy. We see great potential job creation field, gratified Brazil's interest supporting Haitian apparel industry well. But build diversified economy, Haiti needs trade deals. It also needs infrastructure support flow goods services. The roads Haiti beyond inadequate; many communities isolated lack passable road, prevents people holding jobs, children going school, farmers bringing crops market. Better roads could facilitate greater trade bring Haitians global economy. Haiti also needs better roads tourist areas, promote sector economy. Other urgent infrastructure needs include digging water catchments prevent floods, completing garment workers' training center, creating canals help irrigation. As part $287 million non-emergency assistance provide Haiti year, authorized $20 million aid generate jobs, help people put skills work building country's future. We look forward working Haiti distribute money quickly effectively, trigger virtuous circle long-term economic growth. All fiscal responsibility world can't prevent natural disaster. The hurricanes didn't wash away crops houses; also washed away months government planning future. Haiti facing approximately $50 million budget deficit, could undermine Haiti's long-term ambitions well services people depend survive. The United States provide $20 million pay Haiti's upcoming debt service obligations, free Haiti use resources fill budget gap. [There fourth urgent need United States committed helping Haiti resolve. The combined effect rising food prices globally destruction crops hurricanes exposed millions Haitians malnutrition destructive effects health productivity. Malnourished people often weak work; chronically hungry children struggle learn school. Food insecurity source suffering, direct threat economic growth global stability. The United States provide $15-million in-kind contribution food help Haiti continues rebuild. ] These ways United States ready partner Haiti nations. But additional pieces larger mission need support-from helping Haiti adapt climate change future hurricanes won't claim thousands lives; strengthening health systems; promoting sustainable agriculture; developing civil society. This work matter governments, also mission people. Here U.S., I heard many individuals groups care Haiti want help develop don't know invest time money way make real impact. We think creatively helping people outside government get involved meaningful way Haiti's future. Our people valuable resource, potential help places like Haiti yet tapped. We know empirical data small investments go long way. This something I've seen visits Haiti. I traveled husband shortly wedding, years later First Lady. I met doctor emigrated United States became U.S. Air Force Colonel, returned home town Pignon run center health, women's literacy microcredit. He staff resources, offered comprehensive range services thousands clients. I visited family-planning clinic young people trained educate peers protect health prevent teen pregnancy. And I met women group called Women Democracy. These women attended global conference women's leadership Montevideo, Uruguay, returned home, created organization support Haitian women running office. Eleven years later, organization larger stronger ever, mission. In addition supporting women candidates, also hold trade fairs women entrepreneurs, run civic education programs teach women rights, support women journalists, build connections women throughout Caribbean. These Haitian women remind us never achieve real progress leave millions people behind. And demonstrate powerful commitment part Haitian people participate lead nation's recovery. Our role support work however can, demonstrate actions belief future important own. What happens next Haiti send message world power collaboration behalf every poor nation worked hard earn foothold global economy tumbled recent months. On behalf every man woman hemisphere, northern expanses Canada southern tip Argentina, working harder ever fewer resources smaller rewards. children whose futures jeopardized forces far beyond control. let us prove commitment economic recovery reaches citizens individual nations people everywhere.

They surprised see strangers -- five women two men -- sitting chairs boys typically occupy. The students find empty seats shrug matching brown coats mismatched scarves. They curious visitors lean-back, fold-your-arms, prove-it kind way. "I'm James Forman," begins 40-something man. "I'm professor Georgetown Law School -- " "You related James Forman?" interrupts 17-year-old Carleto Bailey. "I'm James Forman Jr." "That father? James Forman dad?" Carleto demands. "Yes, I " "Wasn't big civil rights guy? NAACP? Or SNCC?" "SNCC," Forman says, seemingly surprised Carleto heard father, executive secretary Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee years 1960s becoming active Black Panthers. B6 "He's good guy," Carleto continues. "You tell that." Forman smiles. "He passed years ago, would happy hear this," professor says. He scans room. The Oak Hill students, African American, dressed identically khaki pants royal-blue polo shirts. They chosen seats edges room and, sitting down, pushed chairs back far possible wall. Forman's Georgetown law students -- African American, Arab, Latino, Caucasian -- jeans sweaters. They lean forward, intent maybe little bit nervous. "I teach class juvenile justice law school," Forman continues. "And I thought would really good way law students learn juvenile justice. There certain amount learn reading, also need see experience things. So I thought would learn lot coming hearing experiences." Carleto raises eyebrow. This new one. "And benefit know things law don't. Ya'll certain things know. They certain things know. It learning opportunity everybody." Forman suggests go around room share names interesting fact themselves. Dead silence. He smiles encouragingly. "My name James Forman, I helped start organization, See Forever, runs school," says. Carleto, leaning back two rear legs chair, brings bang sends short dreads swinging forward black plastic rectangular glasses sliding nose. A Georgetown students jump. He looks top glasses. "My name's Carleto Bailey," says. "My interesting fact I'm funny./I He gives wide smile bright white teeth. The Georgetown students laugh. Oak Hill student Ashawntea Henderson, 17, sits next him, rolls eyes. But Carleto's done: "And I'm smart." But turns out, Georgetown folks -- like teachers Oak Hill Academy -- aren't going accept Carleto's assertion face value. They want good grades, right answers multiple-choice test. They want prove think. Forman shows group excerpt film juveniles incarcerated New York's Rikers Island. Afterward, law students want know whether label makes difference. It's hard question. "Inmates? Residents? Scholars?" one asks. "Does matter you're called?" Carleto studies woman's face discern wants hear back. It blank. He struggles. "Not much," says, finally. He looks her. She seems unconvinced. He worries given wrong answer tries again. "Back community, certain [police] patrols neighborhood say, 'I know you're to.' When come home, us trying right, basically criticize us you're already labeled." "What labels?" Forman asks. This one easy Carleto. He sinks chair throws out. "Trouble," says. *** Carleto Bailey trouble. He also, rightly noted, smart. But arrived Oak Hill Academy disadvantages: He poorly educated D.C. public schools, frequently truant multiple run-ins law. The D.C. Department Youth Rehabilitation Services, runs Oak Hill, won't release information specific crime landed Carleto still juvenile, know Carleto's second time detention center. His academic knowledge spotty best. He tell James Forman is, comma falls letter's greeting. ("Dear, Fidel" writes mock letter Castro English class.) He fairly typical Oak Hill "scholar." And, upon time, would written But today, staff fledgling Oak Hill Academy determined view kids' captive time window opportunity fill gaping holes education. Part reform initiative Vincent Schiraldi, director Youth Rehabilitation Services, school opened doors last year takes unique approach teaching delinquent youth. What would happen, Oak Hill Academy co-founders Forman David Domenici wondered, seduced kids content meaningful them? What would happen lots good, caring teachers small classrooms? What one assumed kids could learn -- behaved such? In words, would happen District's challenged students got private school education, albeit campus decidedly different nature? "The bottom line," says Domenici, "is kids risk need highest quality programming, they've gotten worst." It conviction drove Domenici, also school's principal, Forman create three public charter schools underprivileged troubled students District past 11 years. Called Maya Angelou schools, two high schools middle school attack educational deficiencies angles. Students attend small classes taught specially trained staff. The high school day stretches 9 a.m. 6 p.m., three meals provided. Some kids, whose home lives prove chaotic study, offered supervised housing neighborhood. And works. Last year, 93 percent Maya Angelou graduates accepted two- four-year colleges, Domenici says. (According District's Office State Superintendent Education, 29 percent students enter ninth grade D.C. public schools city charter schools enroll postsecondary educational programs within 18 months graduating high school.) It good model. But even though Domenici Forman used teaching court-involved youth -- 40 percent Maya Angelou students spent time Oak Hill -- working inside gates posed new set challenges. Youth Rehabilitation Services court monitor 23 years due part history abuse poor conditions. When Schiraldi took department 2005 began reform efforts implementing less punitive therapeutic detention model Oak Hill, saw immediately changing school essential. "How could I look staff Oak Hill say excellence kids sitting school total waste time 9 3 every day?" Schiraldi says. Kids sat watched movies day. Little, teaching going on, Schiraldi says. "It miserable, miserable school." Schiraldi immediately began lobbying D.C. Board Education hard hire someone new operate school, soon got okay, put request proposals. Domenici Forman submitted plan Schiraldi says "blew ones water," 2007 awarded $12 million contract run school next three years. Domenici's Forman's partnership somewhat unlikely one. Domenici son former New Mexico Republican senator Pete Domenici. He went Stanford Law School, worked corporate law years gave teach work teen delinquents. Forman grandson Jessica Mitford, daughter British baron celebrated civil rights activist journalist. Forman, graduated Yale Law School, worked law clerk Justice Sandra Day O'Connor D.C. public defender. After seeing good schooling options teenage clients had, joined forces Domenici, met mutual friend, start independent school 20 students 1997. A year later, became part first Maya Angelou public charter school. At Oak Hill Academy, principal Domenici fights occasionally maddening bureaucracy basics: functioning boilers, permission college tour group six students, classes uninterrupted corrections staff sometimes call three-quarters students middle class take meds. Forman chairman Maya Angelou Public Charter School Board Directors board member parent group, See Forever Foundation. He attacks hurdles side, fundraising advocating juvenile justice reform. "When David came run school here, like "Ocean's 12": Go find people trust previous mission," Forman jokes. That included past colleagues even Maya Angelou graduates. Samantha Crandal Simpore, then-coed Oak Hill 15 accessory assault charge, went Maya Angelou school runs Oak Hill Academy welcome center. "I tell them, I here, too," Simpore says. She tells new student 17 years old didn't know multiplication tables, rode bus school day hooked Walkman, hoping one knew listening recitation times tables. "I say: 'You're intersection life. You know what's street behind you. Nothing that. But choice what's road ahead.'" Many 90 Oak Hill students, ranging age 14 19, come performing way grade level, nearly half diagnosed learning disabilities. They Oak Hill average 10 months, cycling schedule nothing nine-month academic year. Out necessity, grouped according cell blocks live keep opposing gangs separate. Thirteen-year-olds classes 18-year-olds. More half committed Oak Hill violent felonies. Fights common. (Before month out, Carleto get fistfight hallway delay release date.) Through use small classes -- typically five 14 teens work one teacher, teaching assistant guard -- school organizes curriculum around four-week themes designed pique students' curiosity get think critically nature democracy, social justiCe role world. For example, Relationship theme, students parse types relationships ranging humans natural world (ancient river civilizations) individuals groups (Pharaohs subjects) humans ideas (liberation theology). At time, English class, students working standard five-paragraph essay via guiding question: "Why relationships matter, relationships good bad people?" With current unit, Change, D.C. public school system's learning standards woven social studies curriculum loose headings "Changes Way Humans Think About World Their Place It," becomes way introducing scientific revolution, Enlightenment Magna Carta. It's philosophy emphasizes learning making cross-discipline connections long popular affluent, progressive schools typically eschewed schools underprivileged kids, rote learning return basics often rule. Oak Hill Academy also created course called Advocacy, Georgetown law students co- teaching, emphasizing month's theme. Domenici believes learning law works democracy "is essential teaching good citizens." "We always believed one roles help kids self-advocate advocate behalf community," Domenici says. "We think good skill students individually also one democracy demands." But ambitious agenda, Oak Hill Academy faces significant obstacles. Can teach teens think critically they're missing basic underpinnings education? How teach empowerment setting demands rigid compliance keep kids misbehaving? Although sometimes grows discouraged, Domenici best buoy staff members learn one promising students got fight unit "graduated" program commit another crime sent back. "I talk staff fact that, day day, job absolute best work domain within control," says, reminding don't control pieces puzzle. "And well, done moral thing." His staff members must keep faith straddling two equally potent realities: First, knowledge power, possessing it, every student capable success. And, absent right support, failure lurks right around corner. It sounds like this: "I think Carleto good chance finishing high school going college," Domenici says. Pause. "Also, highly risk that." *** It cold day late January, Oak Hill midst four-week session change. Dressed jeans, blue shirt gray corduroy jacket (the heat's working), Oak Hill social studies teacher John Adams paces around room stops bend Carleto, doodling piece paper desk. "Pay attention," says, taking Carleto's pencil. "Carleto, today's essential question?" "What historical change, different kinds change?" Carleto says, reading board Adams scrawled topic. "Yes," Adams says. He ignores student wandering around room aimlessly, student snatches hat classmate tosses toward hallway. A youth development specialist, corrections guards referred Schiraldi, appears deeply engrossed magazine back room. But snatches hat mid-air, scowls disruptive student tucks hat pocket. "Please sit," Adams tells student. Not quite sitting, quite standing, student perches edge Adams's desk. Good enough. Adams continues: "What's difference personal change historical change?" Silence. "Anybody? More silence. "Ashawntea?" "Historical change like revolution," Ashawntea says. Adams throws list changes -- getting raise salary, moving new house, election President Obama -- Carleto accurately sorts changes micro macro, personal historical. "Obama's campaign change," Adams says. "Do think talking historical change?" He wants students think president, office two days. What might first 100 days look like? asks students. "What advice would offer him?" Carleto looks stumped. "Just throw ideas," Adams prompts. He tells students going craft letters president, advising set agenda change. Carleto slaps pencil desk. "Obama's reading letters," says. He folds arms across chest, skeptical president lay eyes letter -- skeptical, perhaps, teachers really want hear ideas. *** Later, Carleto acknowledge knows quite bit president, reading Barack Obama's "Dreams From My Father." "It started good book, got excellent," says. He struggles hard articulate book's themes appeal. "I don't know put it," says finally, "but growing -- disrespect, -- Caucasian mom African father, still made through." Sitting guard's room gym February evening, echoing sound classmates bouncing basketballs around cavernous gym, Carleto goes tell possibly apocryphal story. "As child, fun, happy -- far kindergarten sixth grade. Starting first grade, honor roll also making school every day," says, beginning third person, quickly lapsing first. "In late stages middle school; end eighth grade, I started smoking weed, stuff I wasn't supposed doing." He takes full responsibility. "No one peer-pressured anything. I liking going I high," explains. He, like almost teens Oak Hill, denies involved gang. Still, Carleto says best friend since elementary school killed 10th grade "a neighborhood thing." "Nowadays, anyone ride you, mistaken someone else shot," says, explaining buddy shot "miscommunication." "It wasn't intended us," says, insisting friend, nicknamed "Smoke," waiting bus. Then announces, "I don't want talk it." So doesn't, though clearly haunts him: He doodle "R.I.P. Smoke" cover blue folder piece loose-leaf paper comer chalkboard. He's happy talk Oak Hill Academy though, 3.5 grade-point average six months. (Domenici says Carleto top 25 percent students Oak Hill tests fairly high assessments.) Carleto likes school even though bit easy him, senior freshman. He complains classes short guards always interrupting move class getting warmed up. That really bugs him, doesn't say much. He says leaving Oak Hill two months intends finish schooling Oak Hill's transition center District, says graduate June. When gets out, couple things wants right off, says. First, intends see girlfriend, go restaurant go "the Adidas shop Georgetown, mom get stuff-- dad, too." He says mom pretty upset got arrested sent Oak Hill. "She was. . . I'm going say kind like surprised actions, I done," Carleto says. "You know say 'Whatever hides dark, comes out?'. . . She ashamed me, disappointed me." Meanwhile, makes long, 45-minute trek District Laurel visit. "Every weekend, days!" says. He alternately vague specific describes family life. He four brothers -- ages 27, 23, 16 11 -- reports two younger brothers live mom. He says mom works secretary, struggles remember where. "She working with, what's program downtown Washington Monument, dealing Smokey Bear?. . . I'm trying think. It's right Holocaust Museum. It's brick building. She works there." Later, Carleto's school case worker, Essence Jones, offer somewhat different account Carleto's life. Although Carleto 12th grade, graduate June says. He still six credits shy, Jones says. And least three months -- two -- release. Carleto's father part life, Jones says. The teenager living aunt coming Oak Hill. His mother, rap sheet dating 1982, jail years, arrested repeatedly string felonies misdemeanors, including possession distribution drugs, well prostitution. She prison since 2005, serving three consecutive sentences totaling seven years assault dangerous weapon, attempted distribution cocaine violation bail. She visiting Carleto weekends. *** By end February, still midst unit change, Oak Hill teens file advocacy class, jostling other, edgy. It unseasonably warm outside, want here. Reluctantly take seats, Carleto positions see patch brown grass mud prison yard, visible door someone wedged open. Occasionally, breeze wafts room. Today, law students decide tackle topic disproportionate minority confinement. If youths color 35 percent general population United States, 62 percent prison population, disproportionate minority confinement, law students explain. They refer teens handout desk front him, article excerpt New American Media, "Racism Juvenile Justice System Revealed," explain isn't simply people color commit crimes: "African-American youths 4.5 times likely, Latinos 2.3 times likely, white youths detained identical offenses. About half white teenagers arrested drug charge go home without formally charged drawn system. Only one-quarter black teens arrested drug charges catch similar break." Although youth color 100 percent Oak Hill's population inmates and, indeed, 100 percent 721 juvenile delinquents currently committed Youth Rehabilitation Services care settings across city, disproportionate minority confinement hard concept teens grasp. Georgetown student Abby Fee tries pie graph, bar graph, sketch disproportionate Xs Os. Blank stares. Then slowly dawns Ashawntea they're talking about. "Hey," says, suddenly sitting forward. "They're switched around! Basically, there's us juveniles prison white juveniles -- even though there's them." "Yes," Fee says. "So population outside system looks lot different inside system." Ashavvntea sits back chair mull over. Fee law students move teens statistics speculative discussion reasons behind figures. They prepared role-playing game coax teens thinking different perspectives. Then, want students practice advocating change. "So, we're going three roles," Fee says, dividing teens pairs. "One group 15-year-old; one group playing math teacher; one group playing city council member." Carleto partner learn play city council member preparing presentation reforming police department. Carleto doesn't want city council member. He doesn't even want today. He wraps unwraps pencil bottom T-shirt. He puts glasses on, takes off. "How could maintain better relationships" police? Fee asks, settling chair help Carleto partner work this. Carleto throws pencil table. Won't answer. She asks again. Silence. Finally, offers sullen challenge. "Stop harassing people reason?" "How want treat people?" "Equally," says. He picks pencil tap, tat, taps desk. Fee tries get specific. "Don't arrest small problems. Instead, take home, tell family you're doing," Carleto's partner says, unconsciously slipping second person. "And think help crime stopped decreased general?" Fee prods. A long pause. Could minds whirring busily; could they're spacing out. Fee, teacher enrolling Georgetown, takes stride. She taps paper couple times repeats question. "Don't 10 15 cars patrolling area barely see police car," Carleto says. "Patrol ward equally?" asks Fee. Carleto writes down, adds: "I see lot cruel things done ain't right." Fee nods, encourages write down. Carleto's partner grabs pencil speaks writes. "The majority police shouldn't carry guns. I could say, 'The majority police racist.'" "But would fix that?" Fee. prods. "A camera car catch they're -- secret one," Carleto suggests. He sits straighter chair. "And don't pull people they're black. They say anything, that's reason I pulled over, headlights whatever." Suddenly, Carleto roll, rattles list improvements. "Call order city council," says Georgetown student Dania Ayoubi. Carleto partner stand front class. "Hello, I'm Mr. Jones, I city councilman," Carleto says, glancing paper twisting tail shirt free hand. "We complaints different communities wards police, suggestions cracking officers." He sounds nervous begins list. "Stop harassing minorities ethnic youths, treat equal race are. Also, police don't arrest situation school like fight anything. I feel arrested taken home. Then tell parents happened reason stopped police." He moves briskly suggestions twice, tentatively, tries actually making eye contact audience. In conclusion, says, "verbally abusing" youth won't tolerated more. "Basically, want crack officers removed, so." Another pair students rises begin presentation, teens interrupted crackle guard's walkie-talkie. "Time go!" guard announces. The law students surprised -- quite done -- politely acquiesce. "Wait!" Ashawntea says, standing up. "We got 10 minutes." "It take five minutes get stuff together get coats on," guard says. "But 10 minutes!" Carleto insists. He Ashawntea sit back fold arms. "It's 2:20. We got 10 minutes still." The guard takes beat, shrugs concedes Carleto's point. He goes back hall wait. Carleto shoots Ashawntea look surprise. His advocacy worked. "Yesss!" Ashawntea hisses breath. Karen Houppert contributing writer Magazine. She reached me@karenhouppert corn.

Clinton urged graduates Barnard College, women's university New York City, show opposition Pyongyang's detention two journalists due go trial June 4. "We two young women journalists right imprisoned North Korea get busy Internet let North Koreans know find absolutely unacceptable," Clinton told graduation ceremony. Clinton highlighting new media tools women use fight injustice around world. North Korea announced last Thursday set June 4 trial date two journalists — Euna Lee, Korean- American, Laura Ling, Chinese-American — gave details charges them. Clinton said afterward announcement trial date "a signal be" resolution case soon, even though said pair released immediately charges "baseless." The North previously said would go trial "hostile acts" illegally entering country. Their trial would held "on basis confirmed crimes committed them," announced. While working story refugees fleeing hardline communist North, pair detained March 17 along narrow Tumen River marks border China. In Obama Administration, use smart power advance shared security, shared prosperity shared humanity. In advancing shared security, seek to: • Reduce threat violent extremism • Reduce spread weapons mass destruction In advancing shared prosperity, seek to: • Use development create sustain strong stable economies by: o Focusing women essential driving economic growth; o Expanding access food means grow buy it; and, o Expanding access quality education developing countries; • Expand access stable, affordable increasingly clean energy sources In advancing shared humanity, seek to: • Expand human rights conditions promote respect human rights • Support development health systems support healthier societies confront spread pandemic disease (e.g., AlDs) How achieve goals: We advance goals shared responsibility application smart power. America responsibility lead, lead partnership others. Smart power means elevating integrating diplomacy development. U.S. DEPARTMENT OF STATE Office Spokesman For Immediate Release June 2, 2009 2009/ Question Taken June 1, 2009 Daily Press Briefing Current results Texting Campaign Humanitarian Aid Pakistan Q. How much money raised texting campaign humanitarian aid Pakistan? A. The United Nations High Commissioner Refugees reported June 1, 2009, total $135,008 private donations U.S. sources humanitarian aid Pakistan received. Of total, $31,390 received via 5,722 text messages. The remainder included $84,702 received via 439 online donations; $18,916 mail major donors. # # #

Barack Obama may support insurance mandate By CARRIE BUDOFF BROWN I 6/3/09 3:42 PM EDT Updated: 6/3/09 11:22 PM EDT As presidential candidate, Barack Obama scoffed Hillary Rodham Clinton's proposal require people buy health insurance. "(If) can't afford it, don't get it," Obama said primary, arguing mandate would work unless insurance costs lowered first. For first time, Obama confirmed Wednesday plans stake different position president. In letter two leading Democratic senators, Obama said could support mandate individuals buy coverage, long Congress exempted could afford it. This marks shift stance campaign, tussled repeatedly Clinton issue. She proposed individual mandate, not. "I share goal ending lapses gaps coverage make us less healthy drive everyone's costs, I open ideas shared responsibility," Obama wrote. "But I believe going make people responsible owning health insurance, must make health care affordable." "If end system people responsible insurance, need provide hardship waiver exempt Americans cannot afford it," Obama wrote. Detailing positions various health care proposals first time president, Obama also said Americans able choose public private insurance plans reformed health care system. "I strongly believe Americans choice public health insurance option operating alongside private plans," wrote. "This give better range choices, make health care market competitive, keep insurance companies honest." He offered qualified support mandate employers provide insurance pay fee government. Employers "have responsibility support health insurance employees," Obama wrote, small businesses exempt. Obama's positions issues entirely surprising, decision weigh congressional Democratic leaders released single bill unexpected. Prior letter, Obama aides declined say specifically stood various issues, including public plan individual mandate, saying wanted Congress lead way writing bill. But Democrats anxious president take public stance, letter provides guidance many Congress craving House Senate committees move closer releasing draft bills. "The president says get done. Get done right get one chance," said Sen. Barbara Mikulski (D-Md.), member Senate Health, Education, Labor Pensions Committee. "The letter essentially synthesizes president saying." He outlined parameters letter Senate Finance Chairman Max Baucus (D-Mont.) Health, Education, Labor Pensions Committee Chairman Ted Kennedy (D-Mass.). Obama's endorsement public insurance option could boost controversial proposal serve catalyst Democratic base president kicks grassroots campaign Saturday. "It's clear Republican resistance public plan hasn't softened President Obama's support one," Sen. Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.) said statement. "This strengthens hand us advocating public option, way keep private insurers' feet fire." Despite almost uniform opposition Republicans public plan, president wrote letter remains "hopeful many Republicans" would back overhaul bill. Sen. Chuck Grassley (R-Iowa), ranking Republican Finance Committee, struck optimistic tone statement, saying letter "doesn't draw lines sand," "is helpful statements reform legislation needs bipartisan support." However, letter likely incite opponents, frustrated Obama's lack specifics. Indeed, Thursday morning, Conservatives Patients' Rights begin airing new TV ad called "Bulldozer," says "government-run plan" drive private insurers business eliminate consumer choices. Back top Read more: "Barack Obama may support insurance mandate - Carrie Budoff Brown - POLITICO.com" - http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0609/23298.html#ixzz0HQhr4KMx&A

FYI CQ TODAY ONLINE NEWS — APPROPRIATIONS June 4, 2009 — 1:39 p.m. War Supplemental Conference Slips Next Week By Josh Rogin, CQ Staff House leadership decided hold conference vote war supplemental spending bill week, leaders worked behind scenes secure enough Democratic votes pass measure absent GOP support. Multiple lawmakers aides confirmed expected Thursday session finalize negotiations bill (HR 2346), mainly fund wars Iraq Afghanistan, occur least early next week. Democratic leaders trying convince many 18 51 Democrats voted House version May change votes, many said would so. Republicans promising vote conference report en mass includes $5 billion worth funding related International Monetary Fund. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., said Thursday would. "I believe people Republican Party support [the IMF funding]; don't want support bill," Pelosi said Thursday, "So Democratic votes." She also pushed back two key pillars House Republican leadership's argument IMF funding, meant accommodate increased U.S. credit extension organization. Responding statements Minority Leader John A. Boehner Ohio IMF money unrelated war spending measure, Pelosi said IMF help "national security initiative" helps alleviate sources instability, poverty. Pelosi also accused House Minority Whip Eric Cantor, R-Va., fear mongering putting statement warning IMF assistance could somehow fund terrorism. "I don't know anyone would say money going hands terrorists," said. "It simply based fact scare tactic, unfortunate." House Democratic aides said conference supplemental bill probably would early next week. "We're going come supplemental conference report next days," said Senate Majority leader Harry Reid, D-Nev. 6 Whipping Votes House leaders planned hold conference session Thursday said House floor vote could early Friday. But effort convince members switch votes still underway Thursday afternoon. • Although several high ranking Democrats pledged switch votes, including Reps. Barney Frank, D-Mass., George Miller, D-Calif., many others said would not. "It's conscience vote," said Rep. Alan Grayson, D-Fla., said inclined change stance bill "I haven't cracked yet," said Rep. Jim McGovern, D-Mass., along anti-war Democrats pledged war funding provide withdrawal troops southwest Asia. Still, many Democrats said leadership lobbying relatively intensely. More Details Emerge Meanwhile, details near finalized supplemental conference report negotiations came Thursday. Senate Appropriations Committee Chairman Daniel K. Inouye, D-Hawaii, said final bill "in likelihood" include money 5 C-130 transport planes 8 C-17 cargo planes, none requested administration Senate's bill. The House bill sought 11 C-130s 8 C-17s. Overall, defense portion bill expected $4 billion less House version still billions Senate version administration request, House Appropriations Defense subcommittee chairman John P. Murtha, D-Pa., said. As fate prisoners Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, conference report likely include language barring administration transferring prisoners U.S. soil remainder fiscal year, said House Appropriator James P. Moran, D-Va. No money towards president's effort close prisons conference report, Moran added. The president requested $80 million neither House Senate versions included funds. John M Donnelly Katherine Hunter contributed story Source: CQ Today Online News Round-the-clock coverage news Capitol Hill. © 2009 Congressional Quarterly Inc. All Rights Reserved. 7

But cast principled difference approach -- problem merely people couldn't afford insurance? something more? -- seems conceded. Here's relevant paragraph: I understand Committees moving towards principle shared responsibility -- making every American responsible health insurance coverage, asking employers share cost. But I believe going make people responsible owning health insurance, must make health care affordable. Rooney) June 6,2009 11:30am Rooney (x7-7203, CONCEPT NOTE FOR WORLD FOOD PRIZE CEREMONY Thursday, June 11, 2009 This speech opportunity signal urgency problem global hunger; connect array global issues, including economic development, health education, expanding opportunity women, political stability; declare Administration's commitment tackling hunger roots, effective efficient collaboration array partners. Additionally, remarks point shift past approaches emphasizing need support local solutions focus long-term sustainability help people feed reduce need emergency assistance road. The speech could framed follows: THE PRIZE AND PRIZE-WINNER You begin announcing winner 2009 World Food Prize, Dr. Gebisa Ejeta. He remarkable story: born mud hut Ethiopia, got PhD Purdue University plant breeding genetics developed strains sorghum drought-tolerant, high-yield, resistant Striga weed, devastates crops across Africa. Outside lab, helped start Sudanese commercial seed industry; developed systems produce, certify, market hybrid seeds; educated farmers use fertilizers soil water conservation. And trained inspired next generation African agricultural scientists. A COMPREHENSIVE APPROACH: FROM LAB TO FARM TO MARKET TO TABLE Dr. Ejeta's work reflects breadth issue comprehensive approach needed address it—one connects labs new seed technologies developed.., fields small-scale farmers labor feed families make living.., markets food bought sold... homes people get nourishment need thrive. In many places, food chain broken. One billion people worldwide woke hungry morning go sleep hungry tonight. Chronic hunger threatens health, making harder people work students learn, turn stunts economic development. Last year's food riots demonstrated food scarce, political stability threatened. 44 To date, world's primary response hunger send emergency food aid. While saves lives, short-term fix, need long-term solution. The Obama Administration committed leading developing new global approach. We support creation sustainable agricultural systems appropriate regions around world, increase agricultural productivity, create jobs, strengthen economies, protect natural resources. We imposing one-size-fits-all solutions, assisting countries carrying individual strategies meet needs—for example, Comprehensive Africa Agriculture Development Plan. To facilitate coordination share best practices, seek convene donor governments, multilateral institutions, NG0s, private companies, foundations, universities, individuals. THE ANCHORS OF OUR APPROACH We've identified seven anchors secure sustainable agriculture systems. These guide approach. • Increase agricultural productivity expanding access quality seeds, fertilizer, irrigation, credit purchase them, training use them. • Stimulate post-harvest sector improving storage processing food improving transportation connect small farmers markets. • Maintain natural resources land farmed well future make right adaptations changing environment. • Expand knowledge training support R&D developing next generation agriculture scientists. • Increase trade small-scale farmers developing countries sell crops far wide. • Support policy reform good governance, sustainable agriculture flourishes clear predictable policy regulatory environment. • Support women families agriculture. Seventy percent world's farmers women, programs offer credit training farmers target men. This must change agriculture thrive. And children must nutrition contribute communities' future. A PREVIEW OF WHAT'S TO COME In coming weeks, President Obama, Secretary Vilsack I reaching share approach global coordination agriculture greater detail. We seek input, wisdom guidance working long arena—from Congress NGOs academics foundations private sector. The President's conversations G-8 meeting Italy two weeks address approach, well trip Africa August. Addressing hunger food essential achieving economic recovery, stabilizing societies, expanding opportunity hundreds millions people worldwide. This supporting sustainable agriculture worldwide central element foreign policy Obama Administration. CONCLUSION You circle back story Dr. Ejeta close. The speech could framed follows: THE PRIZE AND PRIZE-WINNER You begin announcing winner 2009 World Food Prize, Dr. Gebisa Ejeta. He remarkable story: born mud hut Ethiopia, got PhD Purdue University plant breeding genetics developed strains sorghum drought-tolerant, high- yield, resistant Striga weed, devastates crops across Africa. Outside lab, helped start Sudanese commercial seed industry; developed systems produce, certify, market hybrid seeds; educated farmers use fertilizers soil water conservation. And trained inspired next generation African agricultural scientists. A COMPREHENSIVE APPROACH: FROM LAB TO FARM TO MARKET TO TABLE Dr. Ej eta's work reflects breadth issue comprehensive approach needed address it—one connects labs new seed technologies developed.., fields small-scale farmers labor feed families make living.., markets food bought sold... homes people get nourishment need thrive. In many places, food chain broken. One billion people worldwide woke hungry morning go sleep hungry tonight. Chronic hunger threatens health, making harder people work students learn, turn stunts economic development. Last year's food riots demonstrated food scarce, political stability threatened. To date, world's primary response hunger send emergency food aid. While saves lives, short-term fix, need long-term solution. The Obama Administration committed leading developing new global approach. We support creation sustainable agricultural systems appropriate regions around world, increase agricultural productivity, create jobs, strengthen economies, protect natural resources. We imposing one-size-fits-all solutions, assisting countries carrying individual strategies meet needs—for example, Comprehensive Africa Agriculture Development Plan. To facilitate coordination share best practices, seek convene donor governments, multilateral institutions, NG0s, private companies, foundations, universities, individuals. THE ANCHORS OF OUR APPROACH We've identified seven anchors secure sustainable agriculture systems. These guide approach. • Increase agricultural productivity expanding access quality seeds, fertilizer, irrigation, credit purchase them, training use them. • Stimulate post-harvest sector improving storage processing food improving transportation connect small farmers markets. • Maintain natural resources land farmed well future make right adaptations changing environment. • Expand knowledge training support R&D developing next generation agriculture scientists. • Increase trade small-scale farmers developing countries sell crops far wide. • Support policy reform good governance, sustainable agriculture flourishes clear predictable policy regulatory environment. • Support women families agriculture. Seventy percent world's farmers women, programs offer credit training farmers target men. This must change agriculture thrive. And children must nutrition contribute communities' future. A PREVIEW OF WHAT'S TO COME In coming weeks, President Obama, Secretary Vilsack I reaching share approach global coordination agriculture greater detail. We seek input, wisdom guidance working long arena—from Congress NGOs academics foundations private sector. The President's conversations G- 8 meeting Italy two weeks address approach, well trip Africa August. Addressing hunger food essential achieving economic recovery, stabilizing societies, expanding opportunity hundreds millions people worldwide. This supporting sustainable agriculture worldwide central element foreign policy Obama Administration. CONCLUSION You circle back story Dr. Ejeta close. He represents need multinational approach: born Ethiopia, educated United States, advised Indian scientists, advisor several African nations.

Just wanted sure saw Kurtzer op-ed, ran Sunday Post. Kudos Jonathan Prince getting written placed. The Settlements Facts • By Daniel Kurtzer Sunday, June 14, 2009 Faulty analysis Israeli settlement issue passed fact. Charles Krauthanuner's June 5 column, "The Settlements Myth," one example. Here facts: In 2003, Israeli government accepted, reservations, "road map" peace, imposed two requirements Israel regarding settlements: "GO! [Government Israel] immediately dismantles settlement outposts erected since March 2001. Consistent Mitchell Report, GOI freezes settlement activity (including natural growth settlements)." Today, Israel maintains three events -- namely, draft understandings discussed 2003 Prime Minister Ariel Sharon U.S. deputy national security adviser Stephen Hadley; President George W. Bush's April 14, 2004, letter Sharon; April 14 letter Sharon adviser Dov Weissglas national security adviser Condoleezza Rice -- constitute formal understanding United States accepted continuing Israeli building within "construction line" settlements. The problem understanding. The first event Israelis cite 2003 discussions four-part draft included notion construction within settlements might permitted confined already built-up areas settlements. The idea draw line around outer perimeter built-up areas settlements allow building inside line. This draft never codified, effort made define line around built-up areas settlements. Nonetheless, Israel began act largely accordance reading provisions, probably believing U.S. silence conferred assent. Second, President Bush's 2004 letter conveyed U.S. support agreed outcome negotiations Israel would retain "existing major Israeli population centers" West Bank "on basis mutually agreed changes. . . ." One key provisions letter U.S. support Israel's retaining settlements predicated "agreed outcome" negotiations. Despite Israel's contention letter allowed continue building large settlement blocs Ariel, Maale Adumim Gush Etzion, letter convey U.S. support understanding Israeli settlement activities areas run-up peace agreement. In 2004 letter Rice, Weissglas addressed issue "construction line," saying "within agreed principles settlement activities, effort made next days better definition construction line settlements Judea & Samaria." However, never "agreed principles settlement activities." Moreover, effort define "construction line" never consummated: Israel United States discussed briefly reach agreement definition construction line settlements. Weissglas's letter also promised "continuous action" remove unauthorized outposts, Israel removed almost none them. Throughout period, Bush administration regularly protest Israel's continuing settlement activity. But different arguing United States agreed it. In recent days, former senior Bush administration officials told journalists background understandings existed Israel regarding continued settlement activity. Commentators also focus Obama administration's reiteration freeze must include "natural growth" settlements. Krauthammer says "means strangling death thriving towns close 1949 armistice line. . . It means increase population. Which means babies." This nonsense. No one suggests Israelis stop babies. Rather, blessing new baby translate right build apartments houses settlements. The two issues nothing other. Israelis, like Americans, move time life circumstances -- children, jobs, housing availability -- change. The pattern population growth territories actually undercuts natural-growth argument. Since 1993, Israel signed Oslo Accords, Israel's West Bank settler population grown 116,300 289,600. The numbers East Jerusalem increased 152,800 186,000. This goes far beyond natural increase families already living settlements. Inserting provision "natural growth" official documents started 2001 Mitchell Report 2003 "road map," reflecting recognition concept abused justification expanding settlements. The Obama administration pursuing policies every administration since 1967 articulated -- settlements jeopardize possibility achieving peace thus settlement activity stop. This diminish Palestinians' responsibilities, especially commitment stop violence terrorism uproot terrorist infrastructure. President Obama emphasized Cairo speech. But Palestinian failures no" way justify Israeli failure implement road map commitments respect settlements outposts. It time Israel freeze settlement activity dismantle unauthorized outposts. The writer, US. ambassador Israel 2001 2005, visiting professor Middle East policy studies Princeton University's Woodrow Wilson School Public International Affairs.

Longtime Clinton confidant Blumenthal become Clinton advisor Tue, 06/23/2009 - 1:00pm Longtime journalist former Clinton White House advisor Sidney Blumenthal become special advisor without portfolio Secretary State Hillary Clinton, The Cable learned. Blumenthal refused comment. But sources say filling paperwork disentangling obligations moves become special advisor secretary whose presidential campaign helped advise. The position would require Senate confirmation. Clinton, recovering surgery repair broken elbow, building team State Department, establishing credentials team player supporting amplifying former presidential rival's foreign-policy vision. Sources close says prove indispensable Obama, point several Obama aides also made Politico's Ben Smith piece noting relatively background role played early months. The planned addition Blumenthal, longtime confidant Clinton family fierce defender Bill Clinton's presidential legacy, could indicate plans raise profile. (Blumenthal probably Clinton's best speechwriter, friend notes.) In foreign-policy arena, Blumenthal advised former President Clinton U.S.-British relations, first introduced future British Prime Minister Tony Blair. He also active Third Way- Progressive Governance process. A former Washington Post reporter, Blumenthal contributed commentary editorial advice Vanity Fair, Tina Brown's new online magazine The Daily Beast, New Yorker, Salon. Blumenthal also fellow New York University's Center Law Security. Laura Rozen I Permalink I fA9ç%'1 Comments? Login register 52

Clinton Ends Africa Tour, Vowing Stay Involved By JEFFREY GETTLEMAN The New York Times Published: August 15, 2009 SANTA MARIA, Cape Verde - After grueling seven-nation, 11-day trip, Secretary State Hillary Rodham Clinton wrapped Africa tour Friday reaffirming promise renovate American relations continent. "I leave Africa remarkable trip even committed," Mrs. Clinton said leaving Cape Verde. "I seen joy energy Africans have, evidenced boogieing, hard work perseverance," said, referring recent comment husband, former President Bill Clinton, knew "boogie" African dancers. "And we've seen worst humanity itself," added, presumably referring Congo, Mrs. Clinton met victims brutal civil war seem end. Mrs. Clinton seemed satisfied accomplished mission: strengthening American relations crucial allies continent, like Nigeria South Africa, sending message "tough love," called it, nations like Kenya Congo. Over all, said, United States wants work closely African nations partner, simply patron dispenser aid. In exchange, said, African leaders must deliver democracy good government. Mrs. Clinton vowed stay top Africa, even gets back Washington, closely monitoring issues addressed tour. She also pointed Cape Verde, set palm-studded islands best known beaches enormous tourist hotels, example good leadership do. "This possible," said. "You create economic growth sense human dignity possibility." Kenya. South Africa. Angola. Congo. Nigeria. Liberia. And finally Cape Verde. Mrs. Clinton saw eyes Africa's promising countries - troubled ones. In Kenya, pushed government prosecute perpetrators postelection violence last year. In South Africa, big issue Zimbabwe South African government help ease crisis there. In Angola, theme good governing practices oil, strategic concern United States given many inroads China made elsewhere Africa hunger natural resources. In Congo, Mrs. Clinton passionate need end nation's rape epidemic. "The secretary's visit heart world's deadliest war zone eastern Congo potential game-changer conflict," said John Prendergast, founder Washington-based Enough project. "Her commitment addressing root causes conflict minerals power electronics industry refreshing contrast usual disaster sympathy tourism visiting dignitaries." "Now," added, "comes hard part: making good promises living high expectations engendered visit." In Nigeria, Mrs. Clinton pressed electoral changes. In Liberia, praised country's president, Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, woman Africa elected head state. The Liberian visit special warmth, almost like meeting long-lost cousins. Liberia founded 19th century freed American slaves, country's flag, people's names even police uniforms plastic- brimmed hats reminiscent American versions. Mrs. Clinton received possibly exuberant welcome there, Liberian man long wooden horn followed around visit, blowing loud funny noises whenever said something striking. "I love - horn - I want take guy wherever I go," said. In Cape Verde, Mrs. Clinton seemed bones pick. For once, said, cheat sheet country included list far positives negatives. The country fewer 500,000 people escaped turmoil engulfed much Africa. The all-inclusive, poolside buffet resorts feel like something found CanctIn Bahamas. Mrs. Clinton called Cape Verde "a model democracy economic progress Africa." On Friday, every stop, started speech saying, "I bring greetings President Obama." She called "son Africa" said Obama administration, United States determined help Africa reach promise. ###

Report: North Korea willing hold talks US AP By KWANG-TAE KIM Associated Press Sat Jul 25, 4:51 ET SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea indicated interest holding direct talks United States, news report said, two sides traded barbs Pyongyang's nuclear weapons programs security forum. "We dialogue. We negotiation issues common concern," Japan's Kyodo news agency quoted North Korean ambassador United Nations Sin Son Ho saying Friday. But ambassador, speaking New York, dismissed possibility return stalled nuclear negotiations involving two Koreas, U.S., Japan, China Russia, saying "the six-party talks gone forever." The U.S. offered hold talks North within six-nation process returns negotiating table takes irreversible steps denuclearization. Last weekend, Assistant U.S. Secretary State Kurt Campbell indicated chances direct talks North Korea U.S. slim. "Our bilateral negotiations U.S. South Korea collective approach" North, Campbell told reporters Seoul. Sin said five parties nuclear talks "cheated" North Korea, accusing implementing agreed disarmament-for-aid deal. No details given Kyodo report. Sin available comment Saturday. The North Korean mission U.N. declined comment. North Korea quit nuclear talks April protest U.N. statement condemning rocket launch. North Korea insisted sent satellite orbit, U.S. allies said actually long-range missile test. North Korea conducted second nuclear test May barrage missile tests July, drawing international condemnation new U.N. sanctions. U.S. Chinese officials expected discuss North Korea's nuclear programs regional security issues strategic dialogue next week Washington. "North Korea significant topic, obviously one among many," State Department spokesman Philip Crowley said Friday Washington. The U.S. North Korea engaged sharp war words earlier week U.S. Secretary State Hillary Rodham Clinton's recent comment likening regime Pyongyang "small children" demanding attention. At regional security conference Thailand, Clinton also said North "has friends left." North Korea's Foreign Ministry described Thursday "a funny lady" sometimes "looks like primary schoolgirl sometimes pensioner going shopping." 298

Assuming adequate intelligence, go bank accounts, travel reachable assets individual Pakistani officers, raising stakes supporting militants without creating inordinate backlash . Blunter measures coercion, like conditioning assistance, likely counterproductive. Given level distrust us among Pakistani people, would see another sharp swing U.S. pendulum would harden attitudes make greater cooperation difficult Pakistani people accept. -- There may greater leverage giving Pakistanis incentives aggressive. Of course, military's calculation important. I'm sure shopping list days would need balance would move needle AQ undercutting effort get shift strategic focus away India. . From clips: US Responds To Sri Lanka Protest Over Clinton Remark (AFP) Monday, October 5, 2009 AFP WASHINGTON (AFP) - The United States, responding protests Sri Lanka remarks Secretary State Hillary Clinton, said recent evidence women raped Sri Lankan government custody. In letter addressed Sri Lanka's Minister Foreign Affairs Rohitha Bogollagama, State Department noted US government international human rights groups years detailed "numerous cases rape sexual violence Sri Lanka, particularly acts committed women held detention government."
