I know I'm supposed lift head QDDR, thought would like see — it's ideas wanted promoted picked me. AM The Crossroads Nation By DAVID BROOKS Bill Clinton used talk building bridge 21st century. President Obama talks laying "new foundation." But Clinton always vague land side bridge going look like, Obama vague edifice going go top foundation. They vague nobody clear sort country America going 2030 2050. Nobody quite defined America's coming economic identity. In thinking question, probably helps start beginning. Five hundred years ago, agriculture major economic activity. One hundred years ago, industrial production. Now, course, we're living information age. Innovation creativity engines economic growth. Howard Gardner Harvard put together composite picture extraordinarily creative person: She comes little place somewhat removed center power influence. As adolescent, feels outgrowing small circle. She moves metropolis finds group people share passions interests. She gets involved team create something amazing. Then, point, finds problem, related yet different problems concern others group. She breaks struggles finally emerges new thing. She brings back circle. It tested, refined improved. The main point composite story creativity solitary process. It happens within networks. It happens talented people get together, idea systems mentalities merge. Now imagine creative person year 2010, 2025 2050. You living small town Ukraine Kenya place, foreign domestic. You long break go place people gathering think things thinking about, creating things want create. If passionate fashion, maybe go Paris. If it's engineering, maybe it'll Germany. But passionate many spheres, I suspect you'll want America. You'll want U.S. English become global language. You'll want come American universities lead world research draw many best minds corners earth. You'll want American institutions relatively free corruption. Intellectual property protected. Huge venture capital funds already exist. Moreover, United States universal nation. There already people connections world. A nation immigrants permeable say, Chinese society. You also observe America hosts right kind networks — ones flexible intense. Study study suggests America one societies high social trust. Americans build large, efficient organizations bound circles kinship clan. Study study finds Americans hierarchical. American children raised challenge parents. American underlings relatively free challenge bosses. In country you're less likely submit authority. From story see economic power 21st century going look like economic power 20th century. The crucial fact new epoch creativity needs hubs. Information networks need junction points. The nation make crossroads world tremendous economic political power. In 2009, Anne-Marie Slaughter, director policy planning State Department, wrote essay Foreign Affairs laid logic new situation: "In networked world, issue longer relative power, centrality increasingly dense global web." Slaughter's essay titled "America's Edge." That apt. Americans depressed state mind. As China India rise, nearly two-thirds Americans believe nation decline. In fact, U.S. well situated crossroads nation. It well situated center global networks nurture right kinds networks. Building America means everything possible thicken connections: finance research attract scientists; improve infrastructure ease travel; fix immigration funnel talent; reform taxes attract superstars; make study abroad rite passage college students; take advantage millions veterans served overseas. The nation thickest expansive networks define age. There's reason pessimistic that.

CQ TODAY ONLINE NEWS — CONGRESSIONAL AFFAIRS Nov. 10, 2010— 6:25 p.m. House Democrats Plan Schedule Lame-Duck Session By Alan K Ota, CQ Staff House Democratic leaders Wednesday outlined schedule lame-duck session would lawmakers town least two weeks November early December. Chris Van Hollen, D-Md., assistant Speaker Nancy Pelosi, said interview conference call among Democratic leaders lawmakers likely work next week, take week Thanksgiving recess, return second — and, now, final — week Nov. 29 Dec. 3. Van Hollen, poised take next year top Democrat Budget Committee, said unsure Democrats would resolve disputes unfinished business tax cuts set expire Dec. 31 funding federal programs beyond stopgap spending measure (PL 111-242) expires Dec. 3. "We simply identified issues there," Van Hollen said private leadership chat. "Obviously, big issue deal various tax issues. And there's issue omnibus [spending bill] versus continuing resolution. There lot potential issues. We're going try get nutrition bill." He referring ongoing talks possible extension expiring provisions 2001 2003 tax cuts (PL 107-16, PL 108-27), debate whether move omnibus spending bill fiscal 2011 another temporary spending measure, stalled child nutrition bill (HR 5504). Van Hollen said Pelosi, D-Calif., bring issue tough caucus race minority whip — second-ranking Democrat next Congress — Steny H. Hoyer Maryland James E. Clyburn South Carolina. Diplomacy Before After Conflict By Marc Grossman Conflict universal condition,' older diplomacy. While conflict constant human history, nature armed conflict, especially nature 21st-century warfare, transformed. General Rupert Smith identified changes book The Utility Force: "The ends fight changing; fight amongst people; conflicts tend timeless; fight lose force; occasion new uses found old weapons; sides mostly non-state."2 The nature 21st-century diplomacy also changing. To successful, diplomats must simultaneously shape, act upon, react global challenges. As Hans Binnendijk Richard Kugler National Defense University argue, single problem, danger, threat holds key world's future. What matters interaction simultaneity responses.3 The definition victory, too, different today. Twenty-first-century national security success encompass comprehensive definition security, achieved broadest simultaneous application elements national power. This key understanding Philip Bobbitt's concept "preclusive victory," describes "anticipatory, precautionary attention possible futures," requiring expansive integrated approach modern diplomacy, defense, development. A diplomatic strategy designed produce preclusive victory include conflict prevention, successful negotiation, deterrence, preparation conflict else fail, efforts establish order, ensure stability, promote political economic pluralism conflict. Diplomats always participants prevention management conflict aftermath. The conflict prevention side diplomacy occupied much time State Department 1993 1997 Department's Executive Secretary U.S. Ambassador Turkey. Postconflict diplomacy defining issue last third career State Assistant Secretary State European Affairs Under Secretary State Political Affairs 2001 2005. I tried draw upon experiences observations discuss scope complexity modern diplomacy, methods goals needed prevent conflict, diplomacy's role conflict seems unavoidable, contribution diplomacy make restoring stability following conflict. Diplomacy Conflict Prevention Thanks efforts scholars practitioners, make better use methods theory conflict prevention. The United States Institute Peace Woodrow Wilson International Center Scholars two among many institutions taken leadership role efforts. Michael Lund, practitionerscholar, notes present uncoordinated patchy nature preventive diplomacy reflects absence accepted international conflict prevention regime system governance—that is, agreed upon arrangements geographic jurisdictions allocated, functional responsibilities assigned, norms procedures formulated, actors held accountable responsibilities.' He asks crucial question seek "coordinate rationalize" system preventive diplomacy: responsibility tasks preventive action located—early warning, decision act, formulation response, provision bureaucratic political support? Should horizontal, across different organizations actors, vertical, chains command?6 An example conflict prevention meets Lund's tests effort undertaken North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), close collaboration European Union (EU) Organisation Security Co-operation Europe, supported United States, avoid civil war Macedonia 2001. It difficult recall that, September 11, 2001, possibility civil war Macedonia leading international headline. This successful campaign conflict prevention defined remarkable personal institutional cooperation NATO Secretary General Lord Robertson EU High Representative Common Foreign Security Policy (and former NATO Secretary General) Javier Solana. I spoke often period Lord Robertson, Solana, Ambassador James Pardew, President George W. Bush Secretary Colin Powell appointed U.S. representative effort who, along Francois Leotard, EU Special Envoy, played crucial role negotiating implementing Ohrid Framework Agreement. As direct participant, senior NATO official Mark Laity stated insights modern diplomacy conflict prevention drawn effort, including need personal institutional teamwork, importance early engagement trying head violence, need choose right people tasks kind (including 21st-century diplomats act "unconventionally"), necessity able apply appropriate force quickly.' Diplomacy When Conflict Is Seems Be Unavoidable When diplomacy fails prevent conflict, role diplomat changes. The new requirement may justify use force efforts avoid conflict fail seek address underlying source conflict force seems inevitable imperative. The February 1999 diplomatic negotiations Rambouillet, France, designed show world NATO Contact Group willing make one last effort avoid using military force stop Slobodan Milosevic's attacks Kosovo. I Rambouillet Assistant Secretary State European Affairs support Secretary Madeleine Albright. After first day meeting, much chaos I urged Secretary Albright depart Rambouillet leave "negotiating" us junior. My strategy present, Secretary State— administration—could keep distance outcome might unacceptable United States. The Secretary different vision. Albright hoped Rambouillet would end brutality Kosovars, also prepared meeting fail, thereby options avoiding military conflict would exhausted. Her idea seen everything could diplomatically, including continued presence, Rambouillet failure, could excuses taking military action. Secretary State James Baker pursued similar strategy first Gulf War 1991. Baker relates memoirs, The Politics Diplomacy, President George H.W. Bush concluded United States offer meeting Washington Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz followed Baker trip Baghdad show America's commitment avoiding war possible. Baker writes thought proposal three merits: would give administration one last diplomatic opening avoid war; would shore domestic support conflict; would show that, deadline Iraq's withdrawal Kuwait neared, administration something preparing war. The President's offer turned famous meeting Baker Aziz January 9, 1991. As Baker recounts, "I illusions. I assumed talks would unsuccessful within matter days, would war."8 In 2001-2003, State Department leadership generally saw Iraq diversion Afghanistan central war terror. Saddam Hussein dictator menace— "in box," posing immediate, direct threat United States; focus kept defeating al Qaeda Afghanistan supporting new Afghan government.9 Iraq source tension disagreement inside State Department since beginning administration, sought move policy support "smart" United Nations (UN) sanctions toward aggressive posture Saddam. Secretary State Henry Kissinger wrote Years Upheaval second term Nixon administration State Department culture emphasizes negotiability, consciousness side accept.' Kissinger consider trait particular positive time, department's culture negotiability serve good guide institutional behavior senior State officials participated interagency debate leading invasion Iraq. If period surrounding 1970s détente Russia, diplomatic efforts Shah Iran, crisis Middle East resulting 1973 war, culture negotiability longer served good guide institutional behavior senior State officials participated interagency debate leading invasion Iraq. We took part planning conflict aftermath assuming—or hoping—that events either home abroad would turn preparations conflict successful coercive diplomacy rather military action ordered spring 2003. The State Department's Director Policy Planning, Richard Haass, observed "60:40 going war. . . organization could function people left every time lost 60:40 decision."' Haass operating belief Iraq weapons mass destruction; known not, says would 90:10 war. And senior Department State officer resigned protest. The department sought instead try recreate successful Gulf War coalition President George H.W. Bush argued United States allies might compel Saddam submit deployment force region early 2003. If failed, sustained diplomatic effort create broad coalition move militarily later 2003. This possibility broad international coalition lost relevance January 20, 2003, French government announced would never support second UN Security Council resolution authorize use force Iraq. Diplomacy Preparation Conflict Once conflict inevitable initiated, one job diplomats support military commanders getting need make conflict short possible, fewest casualties Americans, allies, civilians. This objective United States pursued Turkey first Gulf War, resulted President Turgut Ozal's support American efforts. The diplomatic effort prepare conflict Kosovo also involved whole U.S. Government governments NATO Allies. To pursue successful bombing campaign, diplomats many NATO countries arranged overflight support Allied forces. A similar effort U.S. diplomats took place invasion Afghanistan 2001. American allied diplomats worked closely nations surrounding Afghanistan, including forging contacts Central Asian states security issues first time order achieve transit, overflight, bed-down rights American coalition forces October 7, 2001, beginning action Afghanistan. Before invasion Iraq March 2003, especially January 20, 2003, similar effort began earnest. Diplomats supported U.S. Central Command commander General Tommy Franks order make war short successful possible limit American, allied, Iraqi civilian casualties. American diplomats worked military commanders seek access facilities U.S. forces participate public diplomacy effort gain much support possible armed liberation Iraq. American diplomats Pentagon officials paid particular attention Turkey effort convince Turks allow 4th Infantry Division transit country create northern front battle Saddam's forces. Although State Department worried size Department Defense (DOD) request Ankara, worked closely civilian military authorities Pentagon try meet need identified Chairman Joint Chiefs Staff. Joint DOD—State diplomacy, however, could overcome negative vote Turkish parliament, reflected strong public opposition war. The way debate using force carried inside government influences attitudes actions conflict well future decisions whether use force. Military force may restore security, cannot resolve political cultural sources conflict. As Rupert Smith writes, "We engaging conflict objectives lead resolution matter directly force arms, since basic tactical level objectives tend concern intentions people leaders rather territory forces."' Smith argues civil-military structure designed make political- military decisions "deeply problematic" distorts decisionmaking many ways.13 In book, Smith imagines debate British Foreign Commonwealth Office (FCO) Ministry Defense (MOD) officials address genocide taking place number weeks Rwanda summer 1994. FCO: What face events Rwanda? MOD: What want us do? FCO: We ought act. Something must done. We can't people massacred. As permanent member UN Security Council cannot seen nothing. MOD: So want us use military force? FCO: Yes. MOD: To what? To stop killing? FCO: Yes. Exactly. MOD: Who want us fight? We clear killing: tribe tribe, force found _from tribe? And Rwanda big country. Where start? Kigali, presumably, it's capital would want airhead. FCO: Well, must international force, course. MOD: And would British aim joining force? FCO: To play part permanent member UN Security Council. MOD: Is Britain lead force? FCO: No, led UN—a proper UN mission. MOD: That take time assemble, probably late stop killing. FCO: Then mission aimed bringing postconflict order. MOD: OK But need clear many British troops currently available. Given deployments Ireland, Bosnia places, many. FCO: What suggest? MOD: What government's priorities? Is contributing force higher priority tasks already undertaking? FCO: Probably not. MOD: In case, UN forces always lack expeditionary logistic support. And want speed deployment force, offering logistic unit would probably valuable contribution. FCO: Will put soldiers risk? MOD: Hardly any." Many American diplomats recognize imaginary conversation, participated something like dozens times since fall Berlin Wall. In American debate, issue also quickly focuses pays bills. It worth stating, least American case, officials Pentagon DOD often legitimately frustrated State Department's inclination promote military missions Pentagon Armed Forces increasing number situations important, vital, U.S. national interests. While readiness volunteer U.S. military forces solve problems around world direct result lack civilian capacity jobs required, leads understandable consternation among uniform. Diplomacy Restoring Stability Following Conflict There many issues—defeating extremism, promoting pluralism, bringing benefits globalization yet benefited, living sustainably planet, nonproliferation— part definition successful 21st-century diplomacy. But getting postconflict diplomacy right—creating conditions preclusive victory—may crucial all. This easy assignment. The concept success redefined fact, complicating assessment. Successful democratic governance economic development cannot delivered certain date, therefore need time patience necessity ground. However, patience limited home countries, "fatigue" often sets in. Thus, potential failure high. Industrial war produced winners losers; today's lines clearly drawn, timeline may longer. Rupert Smith brings clarity assessment: We intervene even decide escalate to, conflict order establish condition political objective achieved means ways. We seek create conceptual space diplomacy, economic incentives, political pressure measures create desired political outcome stability, possible democracy. . . . decisive strategic victory hallmark interstate industrial war, establishing condition may deemed hallmark new paradigm war amongst people.15 Smith's point pressed even recognizing additional distinction military operation carried following Smith's rules ambiguity inherent trying create conditions Smith identifies objectives. Christopher Schnaubelt noted typical military operation unambiguous geographic boundaries (areas responsibility) assign specific units responsible every inch ground cubic foot airspace. There obvious chain responsibilities expected actions individual Soldier Marine ground commanding general. Nothing comparable exists economic development governance tasks, tend assigned function rather local geography rigid hierarchy authority.16 Postconflict diplomacy among defining diplomatic issues last third career State Department. In aftermath first Gulf War 1991, almost 500,000 Kurds fled mountains Iraq Turkey. Stranded harsh conditions, began starve thousands day. I Deputy Chief Mission Turkey. Inspired leadership Ambassador Morton Abramowitz, American diplomats, followed American military forces international coalition governments nongovernmental organizations, initiated Operation Provide Comfort (which became Operation Northern Watch). This "whole-of-government" "whole-of-theinternational- community" campaign provide humanitarian assistance return Kurds homes Northern Iraq. Once home, needed protected, 11 years, United Sates allies, including Turkey, worked ground recreate functioning society protected area Saddam enforcing no-fly zone. These years also punctuated activity Balkans. As Richard Holbrooke recounts, pre-Dayton negotiations Bosnian leader Alija Izetbegovi took place residence I Ambassador Turkey:7 As one Holbrooke's successors Assistant Secretary European Affairs, I watched effort made Ambassadors Robert Gelbard James Dobbins implement Dayton Accords applying whole-of-government efforts postconflict post- Yugoslavia. I picked diplomatic thread Under Secretary State Political Affairs promoting reconciliation, development, political progress, nationbuilding Kosovo. Other postconflict diplomacy efforts Haiti, East Timor, Liberia called upon resources United States governments try create conceptual space development sustained peace. The U.S. effort Colombia, too, highlighted need focus integrated cross-sectoral approach, included disarmament, demobilization, reintegration former combatants promoted justice postconflict society. But main events modern diplomacy's postconflict paradigm Afghanistan Iraq. The key understanding U.S. diplomacy postconflict Afghanistan Iraq recall profound disagreement inside U.S. Government, especially DOD State, whether United States engage "nationbuilding," policy President Bush campaigned 2000. State Department professionals generally proud effort United States made nationbuilding peacekeeping, supporting deployment U.S. military forces participate, example, Multinational Force Observers Sinai peacekeeping nationbuilding activities East Timor, Haiti, Balkans. Most believed nationbuilding, properly funded executed, effective long-term tool integrated modern diplomacy United States. The effort create new Afghan government overthrow Taliban piece classical diplomacy carried 21st-century context.'8 Secretary Powell directed Ambassador Dobbins support regional negotiation hosted Germans Bonn 2001 create new Afghan government. To succeed, Dobbins worked key players, including representatives Iran, support major role United Nations put Hamid Karzai position lead new Afghanistan.' But, Dobbins written, "Bush Administration, overthrown Taliban installed new government Kabul, determined American troops would peacekeeping peacekeepers countries would allowed venture beyond Kabul city limits. Public security throughout rest country would left entirely Afghans, despite fact Afghanistan army police force."2° The struggle nationbuilding also hampered American attempts get sufficient amounts U.S. international assistance Afghanistan. Washington accepted diffusion responsibility there, British taking charge counternarcotics, Italians reforming justice sector, Germans training police. This satisfied need burden-sharing lead success. In addition, postconflict resources focused United States Afghanistan small compared recent postconflict situations, even including Kosovo.' American diplomats followed Dobbins Embassy Kabul years faced legacy lack attention underinvestment.22 The State Department participated many levels National Security Council—led planning postconflict Iraq. Much planning detailed, focused lessons learned first Gulf War. The department's Future Iraq Project, important, would solved Iraq's postwar problems. State capacity take responsibility immediate postconflict administration Iraq, leadership agreed Executive order creating postconflict Iraq structure reported Secretary Defense. There need recount lost lives lost opportunities well chronicled others immediate postconflict period Iraq, although Dobbins's argument that, looking back, Coalition Provisional Authority accomplished great deal trying circumstances worth noting.23 On July 1, 2004, State Department officially open (on time budget) Embassy Baghdad, allowed expansion diplomacy led comprehensive senior civilian-military cooperation. There another important lesson draw recent postconflict efforts: need adequate civilian capacity respond, including role revitalized U.S. Agency International Development (USAID). As journal chronicled article' Ambassador John Herbst, Secretary State's Coordinator Reconstruction Stabilization (S/CRS), office mandated develop whole-ofgovernment civilian response stability operations ensure civilian-military coordination. The Civilian Response Corps (CRC) early stage, ultimately made reserve component, addition existing active standby components. The personnel anticipated represent full range sector experts: engineers, lawyers, judges, corrections officials, diplomats, development experts, public administrators, public health officials, city planners, border control officials, economists, others. Currently, active standby components stepped drawn State, USAID, core group domestic U.S. Agencies. Once congressionally funded, reserves would drawn state local governments private sector. Between January 2008 May 2009, 56 CRC members deployed 11 countries, including Afghanistan planning purposes, realistic plans 250 active members 1,000 standby members ready deploy end 2010. There least 14 countries United States allies civilian peacebuilding capacity—some including stability civilian police, employing wholeof- government "comprehensive" approaches similar created Washington. Several, fact, higher budgets proportionate gross national products America's.25 One way State support S/CRS effort would consider creating new personnel specialty: "expeditionary diplomat." Washington's diplomatic personnel have, course, always one sense expeditionary; majority Foreign Service deployed abroad majority time. But post-9/11 diplomatic experience, especially effort Iraq Afghanistan, means State needs explicit expeditionary nature future diplomatic work prepare small significant number people serve successfully hardest places moment's notice. Experience Provincial Reconstruction Teams Iraq Afghanistan, lessons learned S/CRS, example diplomats pursued careers toughest posts lead State leadership conclude step worth taking. The first requirement would advanced training, provided DOD Central Intelligence Agency, entering diplomats believe want pursue special career path. These entering officers would make explicit choice understand investment extra training would require service hard places, ask diplomats take hardest languages— Chinese Arabic, example—to serve one tour using skills. Since expeditionary diplomats need meet age physical requirements special operations military, State Department could allow people opt "special force" careers long proper training. This would allow flexibility across institution encourage desire whose family circumstances might change time participate well. The department would also need make sure taking career path recognized career beyond norm Foreign Service promoted rewarded. The creation S/CRS symbol comprehensive, simultaneous diplomacy needed future, expeditionary diplomat could form backbone State USAID commitment civilian response capacity. There still key questions answered civilian capacity. In face real world situation, DOD really support State Department—led operation? Will Congress adequately fund S/CRS, including reasonable contingency fund? How S/CRS resurgent USAID work together? Where lines drawn immediate postconflict needs nationbuilding? There seems question path right one, consistent administration's focus diplomacy, development, defense. Success come clear direction active implementation. If combine observations made several authors,' arrive question: What national policies, supported adequate human financial resources, create conditions war bring preclusive victory? Nation building, post- conflict reconstruction stability operations, counterinsurgency strategy (call will) part modern diplomacy years come. But foreseeable future, United States need learn lessons role nation building Germany Iraq." From Martin: The principle conclusion quick visit Israel Ramallah weekend Netanyahu strong position politically, unusually stable ruling coalition. In view, could easily garnered support large majority people, settlers marginal concern. And would given leverage ministers ensure support abstention cabinet. He wants keep government long possible fear leaves garner support right, including Likud, oppose peacemaking. For time being, Bibi uses threat alternative coalition Kadima keep Lieberman tent. But clock ticking. According Tzipi Livni, bring party government now, willing without demand "rotation," provided Bibi serious negotiating peace. But elections grow closer, party members turning idea joining government. They strengthened views recent internal polling shows Kadima 32 seats (up 28 now), Likud slightly 25, Labor 5. Therefore, Bibi intends make deal Abu Mazen, need sooner rather later. The longer waits, less leverage Lieberman likely Lieberman break away oppose next elections. In context, Bibi's negotiating tactics become self-defeating. The process bringing reasonable price uses lot energy, uses lot goodwill, humiliates Palestinian negotiating partner, raises doubts seriousness. Pinstripes cargo pants -- Clinton tailors new vision diplomacy By Elise Labatt, CNN October 27, 2010 12:51 p.m. EDT STORY HIGHLIGHTS • It first-ever undertaking State Department • Approach focus American leadership civilian power • Going forward, diplomats likely wear cargo pants pinstriped suit. Washington (CNN) -- Secretary State Hillary Clinton outlining plans redefine U.S. diplomacy development ahead top-down review taken place year released coming weeks. In essay November/December issue Foreign Affairs, Clinton previews Quadrennial Diplomacy Development Review, commonly referred QDDR. The review, first-ever undertaking State Department, meant balance similar quadrennial review Defense Department projects strategy priorities. The new approach development, Clinton says, focus American leadership civilian power. Both Clinton Secretary Defense Robert Gates talked "demilitarizing" foreign policy, Clinton says QDDR suggest that, whole new set resources diplomacy development, much geared toward fragile states conflict crisis. In article, Clinton painted broad strokes document, called blueprint reforms implemented next four years. Those reforms include modernizing coordinating diplomacy across U.S. government agencies, creating stronger nexus diplomacy development ensuring development undertaken U.S. lasting "sustainable" impact. "Economic growth surest route poverty, expanding strengthening middle classes around world key creating sustainable international order lies heart United States' national security strategy," Clinton wrote Foreign Affairs. She said U.S. ultimate goal development "put business" boosting countries assume responsibility projects future. President Barack Obama laid vision basic pillars policy September United Nations General Assembly released "U.S. Global Development Policy," changes U.S. efforts focus building countries demonstrate good governance economic potential. But QDDR outline put policy practice. Officials say 150-page document detail everything United States conducts multilateral diplomacy, United States undertakes "stabilization" efforts post-conflict areas, State Department works USAID contractors types numbers personnel needed implement new approach. American diplomats going forward, Clinton said, likely wear cargo pants pinstriped suit.

The Republican case ratifying New START bn)://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/12/01/AR2010120104598.html?hpid=topnews By Henry A. Kissinger, George P. Shultz, James A. Baker III, Lawrence S. Eagleburger Colin L. Powell Thursday, December 2, 2010; Republican presidents long led crucial fight protect United States nuclear dangers. That Presidents Richard Nixon, Ronald Reagan George H.W. Bush negotiated SALT I, START I START II agreements. It President George W. Bush negotiated Moscow Treaty. All four recognized reducing number nuclear arms open, verifiable manner would reduce risk nuclear catastrophe increase stability America's relationship Soviet Union and, later, Russian Federation. The world safer today decades-long effort reduce supply nuclear weapons. As result, urge Senate ratify New START treaty signed President Obama Russian President Dmitry Medvedev. It modest appropriate continuation START I treaty expired almost year ago. It reduces number nuclear weapons side deploys enabling United States maintain strong nuclear deterrent preserving flexibility deploy forces see fit. Along obligation protect homeland, United States responsibilities allies around world. The commander nuclear forces testified 1,550 warheads allowed treaty sufficient missions - seven former nuclear commanders agree. The defense secretary, chairman Joint Chiefs Staff head Missile Defense Agency - originally appointed Republican president - argue New START essential national defense. We make recommendation exact timing Senate ratification vote. That matter administration Senate leaders. The important thing bipartisan support treaty, previous nuclear arms treaties did. Although us initial questions New START, administration officials provided reasonable answers. We believe compelling reasons Republicans support ratification. First, agreement emphasizes verification, providing valuable window Russia's nuclear arsenal. Since original START expired last December, Russia required provide notifications changes strategic nuclear arsenal, United States unable conduct on-site inspections. Each day, America's understanding Russia's arsenal degraded, resources diverted national security tasks try fill gaps. Our military planners increasingly lack best possible insight Russia's activity strategic nuclear arsenal, making difficult carry nuclear deterrent mission. Second, New START preserves ability deploy effective missile defenses. The testimonies military commanders civilian leaders make clear treaty limit U.S. missile defense plans. Although treaty prohibits conversion existing launchers intercontinental submarine-based ballistic missiles, military leaders say want expensive less effective building new ones defense purposes. Finally, Obama administration agreed provide modernization infrastructure essential maintaining nuclear arsenal. Funding efforts become part negotiations ratification process. The administration put forth 10-year plan spend $84 billion Energy Department's nuclear weapons complex. Much credit getting administration add $14 billion originally proposed $70 billion modernization goes Sen. Jon Kyl, Arizona Republican vigilant effort. Implementing modernization program timely fashion would important ensuring nuclear arsenal maintained appropriately next decade beyond. Although United States needs strong reliable nuclear force, chief nuclear danger today comes Russia rogue states Iran North Korea potential nuclear material fall hands terrorists. Given pressing dangers, question arms control treaty Russia matters. It matters parties' interest transparency stability strategic nuclear relationship. It also matters Russia's cooperation needed make progress rolling back Iranian North Korean programs. Russian help needed continue work secure "loose nukes" Russia elsewhere. And Russian assistance needed improve situation Afghanistan, breeding ground international terrorism. Obviously, United States sign arms control agreements make friends. Any treaty must considered merits. But agreement clearly national interest, consider ramifications ratifying it. Whenever New START brought debate, encourage senators focus national security. There plenty opportunities battle domestic political issues linked future American economy. With country facing dual threats unemployment growing federal debt bomb, anticipate significant conflict Democrats Republicans. It is, however, national interest ratify New START. The writers secretaries state past five Republican presidents. Unsubscribe The White House • 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue, NW • Washington DC 20500 • 202-456-1111

OPINION DECEMBER 7, 2010 New Start: Ratify, With Caveats The treaty helpfully reinstates on-site verification Russian nuclear forces, senators make clear Moscow don't see limiting U.S. missile defenses. By CONDOLEEZZA RICE When U.S. President Bush Russian President Putin signed Moscow Treaty 2002, addressed nuclear threat reducing offensive weapons,-as predecessors had. But Moscow Treaty different. It came wake America's 2001 withdrawal Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty 1972, first time United States Russia reduced offensive nuclear weapons agreement place constrained missile defenses. Breaking link offensive force reductions limits defense marked key moment establishment new nuclear agenda longer focused Cold War face-off Warsaw Pact NATO. The real threat world's dangerous weapons could end hands world's dangerous regimes—or terrorists would launch attacks devastating 9/11. And since rogue states also pursued ballistic missiles, defenses would (alongside offensive weapons) integral security United States allies. It context consider potential contribution New Start treaty U.S. national security. The treaty modest, reducing offensive nuclear weapons 1,550 side—more enough deterrence. While treaty puts limits launchers, U.S. military commanders testified able maintain triad bombers, submarine-based delivery vehicles land-based delivery vehicles. Moreover, treaty helpfully reinstates on-site verification Russian nuclear forces, lapsed expiration original Start treaty last year. Meaningful verification significant achievement Presidents Reagan George H.W. Bush, reinstatement crucial. Still, legitimate concerns New Start must addressed ratification process and, treaty ratified, future monitoring Obama administration's commitments. First, smaller forces make modernization nuclear infrastructure even urgent. Sen. Jon Kyl Arizona led valiant effort regard. Thanks efforts, roughly $84 billion allocated Department Energy's nuclear weapons complex. Ratifying treaty help cement commitments, Congress fully fund president's program. Congress also support Defense Department modernizing launchers suggested recent defense strategy study coauthored former Secretary Defense Bill Perry former National Security Adviser Stephen Hadley. Second, Senate must make absolutely clear ratifying treaty, U.S. re-establishing Cold War link offensive forces missile defenses. New Start's preamble worrying regard, recognizes "interrelationship" two. Administration officials testified link, treaty limit U.S. missile defenses. But Congress ensure future Defense Department budgets reflect this. Moscow contends current U.S. missile-defense plans acceptable treaty. But U.S. must remain fully free explore deploy best defenses—not imagined today. That includes pursuing potential qualitative breakthroughs quantitative increases. I personally witnessed Moscow's tendency interpret every utterance binding commitment. The Russians need understand U.S. use full-range American technology talent improve ability intercept destroy ballistic missiles hostile countries. Russia reassured fact nuclear arsenal far sophisticated large degraded missile defenses. In addition, welcome agreements missile-defense cooperation reached Lisbon recently NATO Russia improve transparency allow Moscow Washington work together field. After all, North Korean Iranian missile threat United States, international stability broadly. Ratification treaty also sold way buy Moscow's cooperation issues. The men Kremlin know loose nukes hands terrorists—some operate Russia's unstable south—are dangerous. That alone give governments reason work together beyond New Start address threat tactical nuclear weapons, smaller dispersed, therefore harder monitor control. Russia knows nuclear Iran volatile Middle East development North Korea's arsenal interest. Russia lives neighborhoods. That helps explain Moscow's toughening stance toward Tehran longstanding concern Pyongyang. The issue Senate place New Start America's future security. Nuclear weapons us long time. After treaty, focus must stopping dangerous proliferators—not reductions U.S. Russian strategic arsenals, really threat international stability. A modern smaller nuclear arsenal increasingly sophisticated defenses right bases U.S. nuclear security (and allies) going forward. With right commitments understandings, ratification New Start treaty contribute goal. If Senate enters commitments understandings record ratification, New Start deserves bipartisan support, whether lame-duck session next year. Ms. Rice, professor political economy Stanford Graduate School Business senior fellow Stanford's Hoover Institution, U.S. national security adviser 2001 2005 U.S. secretary state 2005 2009.

Support Arms Treaty By PETER BAKER Another Republican senator signaled Tuesday may vote new arms control treaty Russia comes vote Senate adjourns year later month. Senator Judd Gregg New Hampshire, run re-election, said hopes Senate get chance vote treaty, known New Start, right deal tax cuts spending resolution keep government operating. "Start important issue. It fully debated. I leaning towards supporting it," told Andrea Mitchell MSNBC. "I haven't made final decision," added, noting Senator Jon Kyl Arizona, lead Republican negotiator treaty, still concerns. "He reservations, I believe many reservations addressed," Mr. Gregg said. President Obama made passing treaty top foreign policy priority lame-duck session. Under Constitution, approving treaty requires two-thirds super-majority, 67 votes, meaning Mr. Obama needs nine Republicans assuming 58 Democrats stick him. Snowe Supports Senate Ratification New START Treaty December 10, 2010 WASHINGTON, D.C. — U.S. Senator Olympia). Snowe (R-Maine) released following statement support Senate ratification New START Treaty: "The New Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty, known New START, signed United States Russia April 8th transmitted advice consent Senate May 13th year. Since then, U.S. Senate held 18 hearings member Senate Select Committee Intelligence, I worked colleagues scrutinize agreement ensure classified matters properly vetted. Much changed since original START first negotiated 1991, result I supported efforts make certain questions regarding ability verify Russian compliance Treaty's limits, develop deploy effective missile defenses, modernize nuclear weapons complex, satisfactorily resolved. "I confident New START provide predictability relationship Russia thus enhance global stability, importantly, national security. Therefore, Majority moves consider New START framework allows sufficient debate amendments, I intend support Resolution Advice Consent."

Mills, Cheryl D <MillsCD@state.gov> Thursday, December 16, 2010 9:28 AM FW: From Pakistan
THE NBC/YORKER December 14, 2010 The Envoy Posted Hendrik Hertzberg Last night, I unlocking bike windswept Greenwich Village sidewalk leaving holiday party, friend approached, cell phone hand. A minutes earlier, I inside, chatting happily amid buzz warmth holiday party. Now tears eyes. "Richard Holbrooke died," said. Notwithstanding hospital bulletins since fell ill Saturday—critical condition, damaged aorta, emergency surgery—this sudden, awful ending shock, Richard Holbrooke astounding volcano vitality. Everything large: physical size, including ultimate "in face" face, face like Times Square billboard; buzz-saw voice, highly expressive instrument, equally adept piano (a side-of-the-mouth, gossipy wisecrack, often pleasingly nasty) forte (a high-decibel outburst anger indignation, almost always calculated effect); appetites (for experience, danger, praise, power, fun); ambitions (for himself, beliefs, United States, world). He doe-eyed peacenik, diplomat labored long hard seek alternatives war ways end particular wars. He sentimental unsentimentality, romantic tough-guy realism. Unlike tearful informant, known Holbrooke family friend since little girl, I acquainted casual way many journalists editors. He peer well "source," prolific forceful writer whose favorite venues, The New Republic The New Yorker, happened places I've spent working life. He gregarious fond big, splashy black-tie evenings. The last time I saw six weeks ago, November 1st, New York Public Library's "Literary Lions" celebration. At pre-dinner reception, would normally feet, looming large, repaired folding chair behind little table let wife, Kati Marton, bring party him. At sixty-nine tired—that much obvious—but sharp voluble ever. He still plenty do. Not long Holbrooke achieved greatest diplomatic triumph negotiating 1995 end Balkan wars, I asked liked Warren Zevon's wonderful song "The Envoy." He said he'd never heard it. The next day I sent CD. After that, mentioned every single time I've seen him, including NYPL gala, saying puts on, loud, needs lift. And wonder: life drama, liked way. If Supreme Court allowed votes counted 2000, Envoy, almost certainly, would become Secretary State, next decade would unfolded differently. As is, Holbrooke left stronger, positive, creative mark history held post. He certainly die broken heart—Kati Marton saw that—but surely ghastly, impossible demands last, impossible assignment brought rending aorta. He died country surely soldier. And deathbed words may turn important ever spoke.
